pros: Good vision, growth, purpose, and a fun team.
cons: Pace of work might not be right for some people, but the management is very flexible and understanding to individual circumstances.

pros: As a course instructor you receive lots of support & resources from the team, and work alongside some really inspiring people
cons: As well as teaching a course, you'll be expected to also complete a research project. Considering it's a part time job, I think this is too much work to realistically & meaningfully contribute to.

pros:
1. Important mission: teaching women to code
2. Great community of coders and instructors who volunteer their time
3. Good work life balance and no pressure to work past about 5pm or before about 10am
cons:
1. Leadership (CEO) is very self focused and very disorganised 
2. Team try hard but are often aimless and frustrated 
3. Lack of clear vision or goal setting
4. Poor communication
5. Education isn't actually completely free as oft stated. Some courses are paid and this is a source of revenue for CF:G
6. Very high turn-over of staff, and so never a true sense of belonging
7. Team aren't always particularly nice to each other

review_title: Good company but you don't feel as supported as you think you will
pros:
- Lecture material provided
- A lot of events out of instructing

review_title: Most unethical company ever worked for
pros: Great volunteer network of instructors and I hear that there is a new CEO who may be making improvements. There’s a lot of potential as they have a really enthusiastic community of those who volunteer and take courses, but these are funded by “Pros” courses which effectively sell overpriced courses (which are the same as the free versions) to working women in London.
cons:
Ominous history of people having break downs due to work stress and highest turnover I’ve ever seen. Despite being a diversity-driven non-profit (which consults to large corporates on inclusive strategies) they’ve never hired a male team member, and when interviewing men they have been asked different questions to the female applicants. 

Community team is run like the military with zero flexibility or agency over your work. Emotional manipulation is a major control tool and there’s a shocking lack of knowledge when it comes to actual technology. There is zero career development and management seem to think that “running a team” means micro-managing, monitoring team members and resisting any kind of innovation. They also all refer to the team as “the girls” which makes you feel like you work for your grandparents.

pros: Positive impact makes you feel proud to work for the company. Good opportunities to take on responsibility, friendly colleagues, and lots of invites to industry events to build network.
cons: Small company going through usual growing pains such implementing new systems and processes, although management are supportive.
